author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘She Dies Tomorrow’ Review: When Anxiety Goes Viral
description: A film made before the pandemic now feels uncomfortably timely.
content: “I was thinking I could be made into a leather jacket,” Amy (Kate Lyn Sheil) muses to her concerned friend, Jane (Jane Adams), not long into the moody psychodrama “She Dies Tomorrow.” Having flatly communicated her belief that she will bite the dust the next day, Amy is determined that her corpse be useful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Vote for Trump’s Worst!
description: The competition among his cabineteers is fierce.
content: OK, people, I know you’re feeling a little wan and helpless these days. Sure does seem like a long time until November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Another Man Used Covid Relief Money to Buy a Lamborghini, Prosecutors Say
description: A Houston man who received more than $1.6 million bought a 2019 Lamborghini Urus, prosecutors said. Last week, a Miami man bought a Lamborghini Huracán, according to the authorities.
content: A Texas man this week became the second person in less than two weeks to be accused by federal prosecutors of using Covid-19 relief money to buy a Lamborghini.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Cotto
title: Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn: Open Space and Room to Breathe
description: The neighborhood around the Green-Wood Cemetery is known for being ‘spacious and airy’ — an appealing quality in the age of coronavirus.
content: In this season of quarantine, New Yorkers have been flocking to Green-Wood Cemetery, the 478-acre green space a few blocks south of Prospect Park in Brooklyn, for socially distant excursions. Many are also discovering the qualities of its lesser-known namesake, Greenwood Heights, the neighborhood that cradles it on three sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Do You Want to Be a Vaccine Volunteer?
description: How do you sign up for a trial? Who is eligible? Will you be paid? Could an experimental shot protect you? Could you get sick? Who covers the costs if you do? Here’s what you need to know.
content: Maybe you are an altruist looking for a way to help fight the coronavirus. Maybe you are hoping to be among the first to try an experimental vaccine. Or maybe you are just bored or could use a few hundred dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Zelizer
title: The Many Varieties of Donald Trump
description: Three new books analyze what the Trump presidency has meant for American politics and American society.
content: DEFENDER IN CHIEFDonald Trump’s Fight for Presidential PowerBy John Yoo320 pp. All Points. $29.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Chanel Miller’s Secret Source of Strength
description: “Drawing was a way for me to see that I was still there,” says the author, who refuses to be defined by an assault. A new mural in San Francisco is her museum debut.
content: Four years ago, Chanel Miller, still known as “Emily Doe” in the sexual assault case against Brock Turner, wrote a 12-page victim impact statement so powerful that it went viral on BuzzFeed and landed her a major book deal. It also helped inspire Hillary Clinton’s concession speech — the part where she urged young girls never to doubt their own value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fredrik Logevall
title: How Hitler Took the World Into War
description: Benjamin Carter Hett’s “The Nazi Menace” examines the path to World War II and German responsibility.
content: THE NAZI MENACEHitler, Churchill, Roosevelt, Stalin, and the Road to WarBy Benjamin Carter Hett
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Henrik Lundqvist’s Rangers Future Is in Doubt After Elimination
description: The Carolina Hurricanes swept the Rangers out of a best-of-five play-in series, leaving the team to decide whether to bring back the 38-year-old or go with the rookie sensation Igor Shesterkin.
content: When a whistle stopped play with four minutes, 27 seconds remaining in the Rangers’ season-ending 4-1 loss to the Carolina Hurricanes on Tuesday night, the TV broadcast cut to a shot of the longtime goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, sitting on the bench, arms folded, hair perfectly coifed because he had not played.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Seth Rogen and Seth Rogen on Playing Ancestral Homies
description: In “An American Pickle,” the actor contemplates how our forebears would view us, something he’s thought about a lot during the pandemic.
content: We may try to live up to the ideals that our ancestors embodied and strive to lead lives that are less onerous than theirs. But how do they think we’re measuring up, and would we ever want to find this out from them? It’s a philosophical question that is put to an unusual test in “An American Pickle,” a new Seth Rogen comedy that HBO Max will release on Aug. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Sheriff Apologizes to Family of Inmate Who Died After Being Restrained
description: The sheriff, Bobby F. Kimbrough Jr., said he cried after watching video of the events that led to John Neville’s death last year in a North Carolina jail. Portions of the footage were released on Wednesday.
content: A North Carolina sheriff apologized on Tuesday to the family of a Black man who died last year after being restrained at a jail, a day before officials released videos showing the episode that led to the man’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Where Are We? Theatrical Adventures in Digital Dislocation
description: What happens when the edgy Ice Factory festival goes online? A sense of discovery tempered by frustrating technological glitches.
content: The lobby of the New Ohio Theater was simultaneously comforting and spooky on a recent evening. Look, it’s the ticket counter! And there’s the concession stand, now with LaCroix water and Purell. Nobody was buying, though: The place was deserted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: U.S. Health Secretary to Visit Taiwan, in a Move Likely to Anger Beijing
description: The trip by Alex M. Azar II, a rare high-level U.S. visit, is being billed as an opportunity to highlight Taiwan’s success in battling the coronavirus pandemic.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The United States’ top health official, Alex M. Azar II, will lead a delegation on a trip to Taiwan, a rare high-level visit to the island by an American official that is likely to further fray ties between Beijing and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Facebook Must Better Police Online Hate, State Attorneys General Say
description: The call from 20 state officials adds to the rising pressure facing Mark Zuckerberg and his company.
content: Twenty state attorneys general on Wednesday called on Facebook to better prevent messages of hate, bias and disinformation from spreading, and said the company needed to provide more help to users facing online abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What Might Be Said in a Horse Voice
description: Michael Paleos makes us hungry.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This will be a quick one today, because I am writing the column at the same time that the Extremely Spunky Border terrier and I are battening down the hatches before the arrival of the tropical storm hitting the East Coast. You want exciting? Try banging out 800 words before you lose power and internet, all while moving planters and chairs. In the rain. Uphill. Both ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Arnot and Stefano Ukmar
title: See for Yourself: How Airplanes Are Cleaned Today
description: Airlines are fine-tuning their cleaning procedures — where they clean, how frequently and with which tools. This is what the new processes look like.
content: Move over, on-time performance. The new key standard for airlines and passengers is: “How clean is it?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: News on school reopenings — and closings — from New York, Chicago, Kenya and beyond.
content: Chicago, the nation’s third-largest school district, will begin the academic year remotely, after teachers and parents opposed a hybrid plan that would have sent children into classrooms two days a week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republicans Aid Kanye West’s Bid to Get on the 2020 Ballot
description: Republican activists in at least half a dozen states are deeply involved in the effort to get Kanye West’s name before voters, renewing questions about the aim of his campaign.
content: The effort to get Kanye West on the ballot as a third-party candidate in several states is increasingly looking like an operation run by President Trump’s allies and Republican activists that is aimed at diverting votes from Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Is TikTok a Good Buy? It Depends on What’s Included
description: TikTok’s most valuable assets, a hyper-effective algorithm and a community of popular creators, may not be as easy to acquire as the company itself.
content: TikTok is going to get acquired or die trying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
title: ‘Sunless Shadows’ Review: A Harsh Look at Iranian Women in Prison
description: Mehrdad Oskouei’s documentary brings empathy to a tough subject: women and girls convicted of murdering male family members.
content: Mehrdad Oskouei’s latest documentary, “Sunless Shadows,” is a startling, raw confrontation with Iran’s patriarchy. A poignant follow-up to his 2016 “Starless Dreams,” about teenage girls in a Tehran juvenile detention center, the new movie focuses on a group of adolescent girls and older women imprisoned for murdering male relatives. (Both documentaries are part of a virtual Oskouei retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image, running Aug. 5-30.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Stay Black and Die’
description: One woman reflects on her path to protesting police brutality.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Death of Vivek Oji,’ by Akwaeke Emezi: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Death of Vivek Oji,” by Akwaeke Emezi
content: They burned down the market on the day that Vivek Oji died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Pete Hamill, Quintessential New York Journalist, Dies at 85
description: He was a celebrated reporter and columnist, the top editor of The New York Post and The Daily News, and the author of numerous books.
content: Pete Hamill, a streetwise son of Brooklyn who turned a gift for storytelling, a fascination with characters and a romance with tabloid newspapers into a storied career as a New York journalist, novelist and essayist for more than a half century, died on Wednesday in the borough of his birth. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Burna Boy Has the Whole World Listening
description: With his supremely catchy Afro-fusion and a new album due Aug. 13, the Nigerian songwriter, singer and rapper makes music as a true global citizen.
content: Burna Boy — the Nigerian songwriter, singer and rapper who was born Damini Ebunoluwa Ogulu — once thought he’d be content writing the sleek, self-assured party tunes that first drew fans to his mixtapes in the early 2010s. But as his popularity spread worldwide, the spirits who guide his songwriting had other plans for him. Soon, he was taking up broader, more consequential ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Who Gets Counted?
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Earlier this week, the United States Census Bureau announced it would end its efforts to count the number of people living in the country on Sept. 30, a month earlier than anticipated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Election Battleground: Voting by Mail
description: Readers respond to a front-page article about the president’s assault on the Postal Service and attendant voter fears.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: R.I.P. Clarisonic
description: Once it was everyone’s favorite new thing, but it turns out that washing your face with an oscillating brush is not a good idea.
content: Shortly after Clarisonic introduced a $195 electric facial cleansing brush in 2004, Oprah Winfrey named it one of her favorite things, Cate Blanchett and Lady Gaga used it, and pretty much every women’s magazine in America deemed it a must-have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Tech You Love
description: GPS, Spotify, Pokémon Go: Our readers tell us about the tech that makes their lives better.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: Taking Times Journalism to Another Stage
description: With online programming that has included virtual workouts, a discussion on protesters and a night with Broadway stars, the Times Events team has expanded its scope to reach new audiences.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Why N.Y.C. Has a New Health Commissioner
description: Dr. Oxiris Barbot resigned her post after clashes between health officials and the mayor over the city's response to the coronavirus outbreak.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Tennessee Republicans, Once Moderate and Genteel, Turn Toxic in the Trump Era
description: In the Senate primary race to replace Lamar Alexander, two candidates are fighting to see who can better emulate the president. It isn’t pretty.
content: On July 25, Republicans in Grundy County, Tenn., gathered to hear the candidates in the state’s Senate Republican primary hold forth ahead of Thursday’s election. Most of them kept their comments polite and predictable — and then came Bill Hagerty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Williams Walsh
title: Businesses Thought They Were Covered for the Pandemic. Insurers Say No.
description: The N.B.A.’s Houston Rockets and restaurants like Chez Panisse are among those suing their insurers for refusing to pay “business interruption” claims during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: When the Great Lockdown started in Michigan, Nick Gavrilides closed the dining room of his Soup Spoon Cafe in Lansing, had some farewell beers with his workers and set to work on an insurance claim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Aurora Police Chief Apologizes After Officers Handcuff Children on the Ground
description: A widely shared video shows four children, two of them handcuffed, on the ground in a parking lot. Chief Vanessa Wilson said the Colorado city would offer therapy to the children.
content: The police chief in Aurora, Colo., apologized this week after officers handcuffed a Black family, including two children lying on the ground, in a mistaken stolen-car stop that was recorded on a widely shared video and is now under investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Billy Witz
title: Cancellations, Opt-Outs and Virus Cases Put Heat on College Football
description: The University of Connecticut canceled its football season. Divisions II and III scrapped all of their fall championships. And fans were reminded that a college football season is anything but certain.
content: Exactly one month before most of the college football world once expected to start a new season, Wednesday showed just how difficult it will be to stage autumn sports during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Rashida Tlaib Cruises to Victory in a Primary Rematch
description: The first-term Michigan congresswoman, part of a group of liberal women of color known as “the squad,” widened her margin of victory against a Democratic opponent who first challenged her in 2018.
content: Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, beat back a primary challenge Tuesday from a repeat rival, significantly widening her 2018 margin of victory and helping to cement the staying power of the progressive women of color who have shaped the party’s House majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Sally Yates, Under Attack by Republicans, Defends Flynn Investigation
description: The former deputy attorney general criticized the Justice Department’s decision to drop its prosecution of Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser.
content: The former deputy attorney general Sally Q. Yates on Wednesday adamantly defended the Justice Department’s investigation of Michael T. Flynn, clashing with Senate Republicans who accused her of being part of a politically motivated ploy by the Obama administration to frame President Trump’s former national security adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Met Shrinks Staff Again, Totaling 20 Percent Cut
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art told its staff that it was laying off 79 employees and announced 181 furloughs and 93 voluntary retirements.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art laid off dozens more of its workers on Wednesday and reduced its ranks even further through furloughs and voluntary retirements, leaving the museum with a staff that is about 20 percent smaller than it was before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Why Edmund Burke Still Matters
description: He reminds us it’s hard to respect democratic political institutions while disdaining the founders of those institutions.
content: Had it not been for the revolution in France, Edmund Burke would likely have been remembered, a bit vaguely, as an 18th-century philosopher-statesman of extravagant rhetorical gifts but frustratingly ambivalent views. The Irish-born member of the British Parliament was sympathetic to the grievances of the American colonies but not (like his onetime friend Thomas Paine) an enthusiastic champion of their independence; an acerbic critic of George III but a firm defender of monarchy; a staunch opponent of English rapacity in India but a supporter of British Empire; an advocate for the gradual emancipation of at least some slaves, but no believer in equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Jazz Drummer’s Fight to Keep His Own Heart Beating
description: Milford Graves devoted himself to studying the rhythms of the heart. It turns out he was creating a technique to treat himself.
content: In the 1960s, Milford Graves became a groundbreaking drummer in avant-garde jazz, but intertwined with his career had been his constant study of music’s impact on the human heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Major U.S. Health Insurers Report Big Profits, Benefiting From the Pandemic
description: Consumers are probably entitled to millions of dollars in rebates under Obamacare rules that cap companies’ profits.
content: The nation’s leading health insurers are experiencing an embarrassment of profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Faysal Itani
title: Why Did Lebanon Let a Bomb-in-Waiting Sit in a Warehouse for 6 Years?
description: Yesterday’s explosion, which destroyed Beirut’s port, much of the city and countless lives, was the result of business as usual.
content: My first summer job was at the port of Beirut. It was the late ’90s and I was just a teenager. I spent muggy months entering shipping data as part of an ambitious new program to move the port from analog to digital log keeping. It was as unglamorous as you would expect from a bottom-rung job in the bowels of a Middle East bureaucracy. But despite the heat and the monotony, there was optimism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Digital Revenue Exceeds Print for 1st Time for New York Times Company
description: The pandemic squeezed advertising for the web as well as print, but subscription growth was the best ever for a quarter.
content: Over a three-month period dominated by the coronavirus pandemic and a slowdown in advertising, The New York Times Company for the first time reported quarterly revenue that owed more to digital products than to the print newspaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Peanut Butter and Ranch Dressing: What Americans Abroad Miss From Home
description: With virus cases in the United States rising and international travel curtailed, many Americans do not know when they will be able to reunite with home and the comforts they associate with it.
content: MUNICH — The box was in transit for nearly two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Mail Voting’s Latest Test
description: Kris Kobach falls, and Cori Bush rises: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Yesterday was another mid-pandemic primary night, and early signs are that it went pretty well. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: Biden Announces $280 Million Fall Ad Buy Across 15 States
description: By far the biggest reservation of the 2020 race by either campaign, it is a sign of the swift turnabout in Joe Biden’s finances since he became the presumptive Democratic nominee.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign announced a $280 million fall advertising blitz on Wednesday, outlining plans for $220 million in television and $60 million in digital ads across 15 states in the lead-up to the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Why the Mueller Investigation Failed
description: Jeffrey Toobin’s “True Crimes and Misdemeanors” examines the battle over the Mueller report and how Donald Trump prevailed.
content: Thanks to Robert S. Mueller’s Russia investigation, we know that the Kremlin used underhanded tactics to help Donald Trump win the 2016 election, that the Trump campaign tacitly welcomed those efforts and that Trump ultimately attempted to end the Mueller inquiry itself. But in what passes for political discourse today, the report’s damning examples of presidential abuse of power were spun as anti-Trump propaganda. Mueller himself, a once-revered law enforcement official and rock-ribbed Republican, was smeared and diminished by the president’s allies as a left-leaning hack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: We’ve Hit a Pandemic Wall
description: New data show that Americans are suffering from record levels of mental distress.
content: I am trying to think of when I first realized we’d all run smack into a wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
title: Liability Shield Is a Stumbling Block as Lawmakers Debate Relief
description: Athletes have joined workers who believe legal protections for corporations are not warranted. Senate Republicans support a shield but the White House has been noncommittal.
content: WASHINGTON — Calls to protect corporations and schools from legal blame if workers fall ill from Covid-19 contracted on the job have incited a growing backlash as Congress and the White House negotiate over liability protections in economic relief legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Rafiki’ and ‘Big Brother’
description: A forbidden love story comes to Criterion. And a longstanding game show begins its 22nd season.
content: RAFIKI (2019) Stream on Criterion. Not only is this love story controversial in Kenya, where “Rafiki” was filmed — it is illegal. The movie itself is illegal, too; it was banned in Kenya two weeks before its premiere at the 2018 Cannes Film Festival, where it was the first ever Kenyan film to be shown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt
title: Eric Bentley, Critic Who Provoked Lovers of Broadway, Dies at 103
description: Mr. Bentley, who was also a playwright, was an early champion of modern European drama in the 1940s but had little use for American plays.
content: Eric Bentley, an influential theater critic — as well as a scholar, author and playwright — who was an early champion of modern European drama and an unsparing antagonist of Broadway, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: German Banks Push Back as American Investors Seek More Influence
description: A drive by buyout firm Cerberus to force cost cutting at Commerzbank has run into resistance from Berlin.
content: A few weeks ago the American private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management seemed to be on the cusp of provoking a major shake-up in German banking after it pressured the two top executives of the country’s second-largest lender to quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: After Isaias, More Than 2 Million Still Without Power in New York Area
description: Utilities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut raced to restore power, but officials said it might take several days, in some cases.
content: An owner of a bar and restaurant in a New Jersey suburb wondered if he would stay in business after an outdoor seating area, newly opened after months of lockdown, was nearly wiped out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A Memorable Golf Course Honors a Forgettable President
description: This week’s P.G.A. Championship site is named for Warren G. Harding. The course’s reputation has fared better than his did.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Had President Warren G. Harding not been bedridden in those midsummer days of 1923, he might have left his eighth-floor suite at the Palace Hotel and headed to the southwestern edge of the city, where a new golf course named Lake Merced Golf Links was under construction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Lincoln Library Cancels Exhibition Over Racial Sensitivity Concerns
description: The library, in Springfield, Ill., said Black community leaders who previewed it feared parts of the traveling exhibition, created 15 years ago, were outdated and lacked context.
content: The exhibition on domestic terrorism had been on tour since 2006 and had previously been displayed at four presidential libraries and museums, including the George H.W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum in College Station, Texas, last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Beirut, Hiroshima, “Indian Matchmaking”: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar
title: Modi Founds Temple on Mosque’s Ruins, in Triumphal Moment for Hindu Base
description: In a ceremony in Ayodhya, a past flash point for sectarian violence, India’s prime minister offers his Hindu nationalist base a clear symbol of ascendancy.
content: NEW DELHI — In a moment of triumph that India’s Hindu nationalists had worked toward for years, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday set the ceremonial cornerstone for a new Hindu temple at the site of a destroyed mosque in Ayodhya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Split 5 to 4, Supreme Court Rules for California Jail Over Virus Measures
description: In dissent, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said officials overseeing the jail had failed to safeguard the health of the people housed there.
content: WASHINGTON — By a 5-to-4 vote, the Supreme Court on Wednesday sided with officials at a California jail in a dispute over the adequacy of its response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Star Technologist Who Crossed Google Sentenced to 18 Months in Prison
description: Anthony Levandowski, a onetime star Silicon Valley engineer of self-driving cars, had pleaded guilty to stealing trade secrets.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Anthony Levandowski, a pioneer of self-driving car technology in Silicon Valley, had once been feted by companies such as Google and Uber for his engineering expertise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reyhan Harmanci
title: After a Backyard Dinner, Coronavirus Chaos Ensues
description: When my husband’s cousin tested positive, all of the months of pandemic headlines converged.
content: It started with a text. Or perhaps it was the phone call. Or perhaps it’s more accurate to say it really started the week before, when my husband mentioned that his cousin S., who lives far away, would be visiting the area and wanted to come over for dinner in our Hudson, N.Y., backyard, and I paused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: House Hunting in Iceland: A Lakeside Cabin for Under $800,000
description: The country’s swift and successful response to the pandemic has enabled its real estate market to stay open, encouraging an influx of domestic buyers.
content: This four-bedroom summer house is perched on a green hill overlooking Lake Thingvellir, the largest lake in Iceland, in the rural southwest region of Grafningshreppur, about 30 miles east of Reykjavik.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: State Dept. Traces Russian Disinformation Links
description: A new government report avoids direct discussion of American election interference by Moscow, despite lawmakers’ call for more information.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia continues to use a network of proxy websites to spread pro-Kremlin disinformation and propaganda in the United States and other parts of the West, according to a State Department report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Goodman and Andrew Weissmann
title: James Comey Wrote a Letter in 2016. What Will Bill Barr Do?
description: Two investigations appear to be potential fodder for pre-election political machinations.
content: Today, Wednesday, marks 90 days before the presidential election, a date in the calendar that is supposed to be of special note to the Justice Department. That’s because of two department guidelines, one a written policy that no action be influenced in any way by politics. Another, unwritten norm urges officials to defer publicly charging or taking any other overt investigative steps or disclosures that could affect a coming election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Enjoy Those Vegetables, but Don’t Forget to Save Some Seeds
description: After the unprecedented demand for seed last spring, gardeners may want to plan ahead for the next growing season. It’s easier than you think.
content: In gardening, what looks like a mishap may be an epiphany in disguise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenya’s Unusual Solution to the School Problem: Cancel the Year and Start Over
description: Some students were taking classes online, while others couldn’t. So the government scrapped the school year for all. But the move may just make educational inequality worse.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — For Esther Adhiambo, this year was supposed to be a year of endings and new beginnings. She was expecting to complete high school, enroll in a university and get a job to help her single mother, who runs a small tailoring business in Nairobi’s Mathare slum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: I Was Bloodied and Dazed. Beirut Strangers Treated Me Like a Friend.
description: In a land conditioned by calamity, people knew what to do, including helping wounded people they didn’t know.
content: BEIRUT — I was just about to look at a video a friend had sent me on Tuesday afternoon — “the port seems to be burning,” she said — when my whole building shook, as if startled, by the deepest boom I’d ever heard. Uneasily, naïvely, I ran to the window, then back to my desk to check for news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon: Trump’s Latest Interview Made His Briefings Look Good
description: The “Axios on HBO” interview was “such a disaster, at one point FEMA showed up and wrapped Trump in a foil blanket,” the “Tonight Show” host said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: An Incomplete Census Hurts Everyone. Even Trump.
description: The president doesn’t realize his supporters will lose out too if the count is brought to an early close.
content: The Census Bureau hasn’t offered a clear explanation for its decision this week to bring an early end to the decennial enumeration of the nation’s population, but the reason is clear enough: The Trump administration doesn’t want a complete count, as the law requires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: These Republicans Have a Confession: They’re Not Voting for Trump Again
description: A set of voter testimonials hopes to convince Biden-curious Republicans that they’re not alone.
content: The man — bearded, shirtless, a Marlboro Light clutched between two fingers as it smolders uncomfortably close to his temple — looks as if he has something heavy he wants to get off his chest. Like a person attending his first Alcoholics Anonymous meeting, he seems at once eager and apprehensive. “Hi, my name is Josh. I live in North Carolina, and I voted for Donald Trump,” he begins, in a tone of abject resignation. He cocks his head and rolls his eyes. “My bad, fam,” he apologizes. “Not my proudest moment. I will not be voting for him again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: The Covid Drug Wars That Pitted Doctor vs. Doctor
description: How much freedom should front-line clinicians have in treating Covid-19 patients with unproven drugs? The question opened up a civil war in some hospitals.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Katie Glueck
title: Kris Kobach Loses Kansas Senate Primary, Easing Republican Worries
description: In Missouri, Cori Bush, a progressive activist, upset the 10-term incumbent William Lacy Clay Jr., marking another major step forward for the progressive movement in its bid to threaten centrist officials.
content: Kansas Republicans on Tuesday soundly rejected the Senate bid of Kris W. Kobach, a polarizing figure in state politics and a staunch ally of President Trump’s, choosing instead to nominate a conservative congressman who was the preferred choice of party leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Let This Blueberry Bundt Cake Pull You Out of Your Baking Rut
description: You don’t need a special occasion for this showstopping treat, finished with a jewel-toned glaze.
content: My loaf pan has gotten a mighty workout amid the pandemic baking frenzy. But not so much the Bundt pan, which had been languishing in a high cabinet, waiting for an occasion grand enough to warrant its ornateness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Virus ‘Checkpoints’ in N.Y.C. to Enforce Travel Rules? Well, Not Exactly
description: The mayor is sending the sheriff to city bridges and tunnels to try to ward off a second wave of the coronavirus.
content: The announcement by Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday seemed to signal a new crackdown in the city’s efforts to curb the spread of the coronavirus: “Traveler registration checkpoints” would be set up at bridges and tunnels, conjuring images of police officers stopping cars and detaining people from out of state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Henry Fountain
title: It’s Trump Jr. vs. Trump Sr. Over an Alaskan Mineral Mine
description: The move toward opening the Pebble Mine has surfaced a rare dispute between Donald Trump Jr. and his father’s administration.
content: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump Jr., President Trump’s eldest son, took a break this week from his relentless Twitter attacks on Democrats to express his concern toward a different target: his father’s administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: James Powers, Brooklyn Gallerist Who Nurtured Black Artists, Dies at 80
description: Openings at Mr. Powers’s Spiral Gallery on Vanderbilt Avenue were rollicking festivals of art and jazz featuring emerging artists from the neighborhood and beyond.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Progressive Victories Signal Staying Power for the Movement
description: After Bernie Sanders fell to Joe Biden, the young left mourned what could have been. Now, after a series of victories in congressional races, it’s hopeful again.
content: When Bernie Sanders lost to Joseph R. Biden Jr., the left mourned what could have been, worried that it had faltered at a once-in-a-generation crossroads for the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: With TikTok Mired in Uncertainty, Facebook Pounces With Instagram Reels
description: Instagram, which is owned by Facebook, rolled out a new product that lets people create 15-second videos and share them.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — As the Chinese-owned video app TikTok works to head off the threat of a ban in the United States, Facebook has sensed opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Racial Injustice and Corporate America
description: Advocates for racial equality have long pointed out the uneven playing field in the business world. What can companies do to fix it?
content: Today, we have a special newsletter to coincide with our DealBook Debrief call tomorrow with Nikole Hannah-Jones, the creator of The 1619 Project. We hope you can join us for what will be an important discussion — read on for the details. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill, Stella Cooper, Christiaan Triebert, Christoph Koettl, Drew Jordan, Dmitriy Khavin and John Ismay
title: What Footage of the Beirut Explosion Tells Us About the Blast
description: The videos offer clues into the blast’s cause and the strength of its destructive power.
content: The massive explosion in Beirut’s port on Tuesday shattered windows more than a mile away and sent a plume of smoke and debris soaring above the city’s tallest buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Japan’s Locked Borders Shake the Trust of Its Foreign Workers
description: A pandemic policy that bars re-entry for many permanent and long-term residents has upended many lives and undercut Tokyo’s efforts to woo global capital and talent.
content: TOKYO — When Jeff Mazziotta, a director of a nonprofit wildlife conservation organization, left Japan for South Africa in early March, he planned to spend a month training park rangers on emergency field medicine before returning to Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love 21st-Century Composers
description: We asked Ivo van Hove, Justin Peck, Du Yun and others to pick the music that moves them. Listen to their choices.
content: In the past, we’ve asked some of our favorite artists to choose the five minutes or so they would play to make their friends fall in love with classical music, the piano, opera, the cello and Mozart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: When You’re at Home, You Get to Noticing Things
description: A reader asks how to clean her wooden dining chairs.
content: Welcome. The mission of At Home is to help our readers live a full and cultured life during the pandemic. Sometimes that means telling you what we think about Beyoncé’s “Black Is King.” Other times it means figuring out whether you should travel this year. Always it means telling you to make chicken shawarma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: It’s Never Too Late to Pursue a Dream, a Graduate Says. He Can Back It Up.
description: Sidetracked by poverty, World War II and family commitments, Giuseppe Paternò finally got his degree at 96. With honors, no less.
content: ROME — Six weeks shy of his birthday, Giuseppe Paternò fulfilled the dream of a lifetime: He got a university degree.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Postal Service Funding Dispute Complicates Impasse Over U.S. Virus Stimulus
description: Virginia released the first coronavirus contact-tracing app to employ software by Google and Apple. The mayor of Los Angeles said that the city could cut off power to homes that host large gatherings. The W.H.O. said test results for North Korea’s first suspected case were “inconclusive.”
content: Top lawmakers remained nowhere close to an agreement on Wednesday for a new economic rescue package amid the recession,  and appeared to be growing increasingly pessimistic that they could meet a self-imposed Friday deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanjena Sathian
title: We Need to Talk About ‘Indian Matchmaking’
description: The Netflix show is controversial. But it tells awkward truths about my community.
content: Five years ago, I met with a matchmaker. I was reporting a feature on India’s $50-billion marriage-industrial complex — which includes everything from the dating app Dil Mil to the lavish wedding of Priyanka Chopra and Nick Jonas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Can a Physically Taxing Job Be Bad for Our Brains?
description: Physical demands required for work may have negative consequences for brain health, a new study suggests.
content: Regular exercise helps to bulk up our brains and improve thinking skills, numerous studies show. But physically demanding jobs, even if they are being carried out in an office, might have a different and opposite effect, according to a provocative new study of almost 100 older people and their brains and work histories. It finds that men and women who considered their work to be physically draining tended to have smaller memory centers in their brains and lower scores on memory tests than other people whose jobs felt less physically taxing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: The Milwaukee Bucks Are Ready for a Long Stay in the Bubble
description: In this week's newsletter, Marc Stein discusses the unusual way the Bucks have prepared for a run to the finals — and why the Los Angeles Clippers may meet them there.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Pinkham
title: ‘The Lost Pianos of Siberia,’ and the Lost Individuals Who Played Them
description: Sophy Roberts goes on a quest for a rare instrument, and discovers a vast, uncharted history along the way.
content: THE LOST PIANOS OF SIBERIA By Sophy Roberts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: The Many Symptoms of Covid-19
description: From a sniffle or cough that feels like allergies to severe body aches and crippling fatigue, the symptoms of coronavirus can be unpredictable from head to toe.
content: For a Texas nurse, the first sign that something was wrong happened while brushing her teeth — she couldn’t taste her toothpaste. For a Georgia attorney, it was hitting a wall of fatigue on a normally easy run. When a Wisconsin professor fell ill in June, he thought a bad meal had upset his stomach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Patricia Mazzei
title: If Public Schools Are Closed, Should Private Schools Have to Follow?
description: A dispute in Maryland over whether prestigious private schools can teach in person during the coronavirus pandemic highlights a national divide.
content: Facing a resurgence of the coronavirus, public schools in the suburbs of the nation’s capital decided in recent weeks that more than a million children would start the school year from home. On Friday, officials in Maryland’s most populous county said that private schools, including some of the nation’s most elite, had to join them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘La Llorona’ Review: The General in His Horrific Labyrinth
description: The Weeping Woman returns in a thoughtfully creepy Guatemalan movie in which real-life terrors commingle with genre frights.
content: The curse that keeps on giving, the weeping woman known as La Llorona, is back. The last time this specter worked her mojo onscreen, in the “Conjuring” horror franchise, she terrified a Los Angeles family. She goes after a more obviously deserving target in her most recent outing, “La Llorona,” a thoughtful, low-key Guatemalan movie that deploys its genre shocks inside a sober art-house package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Andrew Higgins
title: Blame for Beirut Explosion Begins With a Leaky, Troubled Ship
description: The bleak tale of chronic negligence started over six years ago, when an indebted vessel and its volatile cargo pulled into port. It ended on Tuesday in a giant explosion.
content: CAIRO — The countdown to catastrophe in Beirut started more than six years ago when a troubled, Russian-leased cargo ship made an unscheduled stop at the city’s port.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Can N.Y.C. Reopen Schools? The Whole Country Is Watching
description: The city’s low infection rate has raised hopes that students can return to classrooms next month. But many obstacles remain.
content: With about a month to go before New York City schools are scheduled to reopen, the city is confronting a torrent of logistical issues and political problems that could upend Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambition to make New York one of the few major districts in the country to bring students back into classrooms this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Cori Bush Defeats William Lacy Clay in a Show of Progressive Might
description: The upset of the veteran congressman from St. Louis sent tremors though the Democratic establishment in Missouri and Washington, D.C.
content: ST. LOUIS — Cori Bush, a progressive activist and a leader of the swelling protest movement for racial justice, toppled Representative William Lacy Clay Jr. of Missouri in a Democratic primary on Tuesday, notching the latest in a stunning string of upsets against the party establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise
title: Teachers, Show Us How the Coronavirus Is Changing Your Classroom
description: We want to see how educators are preparing school buildings to keep themselves and their students safe if they open amid the pandemic.
content: With masks and face shields, plastic covers on books and a disinfecting schedule for classroom materials, this school year will look like none other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Marcus Payadue
title: Progressives, School Reopenings, Beirut: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Member of Conservative Think Tank Takes On Reporter Duties on Air Force Two
description: Instead of a member of the White House press corps, the role of pool reporter was filled by Robert B. Bluey, a vice president at the Heritage Foundation.
content: WASHINGTON — When Vice President Mike Pence traveled to an event in Florida on Wednesday, he was not accompanied on his plane by a member of the White House press corps, as is typically the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Keenan
title: Coming of Age Amid the Troubles
description: In “Inventory,” Darran Anderson sorts through the objects and memories of his 1980s Northern Ireland adolescence.
content: INVENTORY A MemoirBy Darran Anderson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Meet Members of a Historic University of California Class
description: Wednesday: Latinos were the largest group of Californians admitted to the university’s freshman class. Also: A deeper look at the life of Representative Karen Bass.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Beirut Explosions
description: More than 100 people were killed, and the second blast was felt as far away as Cyprus. An investigation and a search for survivors are underway.
content: A pair of explosions, the second much bigger than the first, struck the city of Beirut early Tuesday evening, killing at least 100 people, wounding more than 4,000 and causing widespread damage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020.
content: An article on Sunday about a far-right network in Germany misstated one of the uses of quicklime. It can be used to mask the stench of decomposing bodies, not to decompose organic material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: How to Help Lebanon After Beirut Explosion
description: As the search for survivors continues, aid groups have mobilized to help treat the thousands of people wounded by the blast, which could be felt more than 150 miles away.
content: The enormous explosion that leveled parts of Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday killed more than 100 people and injured more than 4,000 others, overwhelming the authorities and damaging many hospitals and critical facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Doing Away With Convention
description: Do we really need the spectacle of the traditional political conventions? We’re about to find out.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: The Biggest Bedroom Is No Longer a ‘Master’
description: The term’s racist and sexist undertones lead New York’s real estate community and others to rethink outdated industry jargon.
content: Following the lead of other real estate brokerage communities around the country, several industry groups in New York are planning to eliminate the term “master bedroom” from floor plan descriptions and conversations between real estate agents and clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lina Mounzer
title: It Sounded Like the World Itself Was Breaking Open
description: After the explosions at the Beirut port, an immense rage rises against the corrupt and incompetent political class that has ruled for so long.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — It began as a rumble. A deep bass rattling through the building. And then a roar for seven, eight, nine seconds, an eternity. A sound that could be made only by the world itself breaking open. I was certain it was an earthquake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Hiroshima 75th Anniversary: Preserving Survivors’ Message of Peace
description: Hibakusha, as they are known in Japan, were a diminished presence at a memorial event because of advancing age and the coronavirus.
content: TOKYO — The hibakusha, as the survivors of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki are known in Japan, have achieved a powerful feat of alchemy, transforming their nightmarish memories of the blasts and their aftermath into a visceral force for promoting a world free of nuclear arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miles Peyton
title: What happens when you plant a mystery seed?
description: The answer will shock you
content: You’ll never believe what happened when someone planted a mystery seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump Cherry-Picks Coronavirus Data in Briefing Appearance
description: The president selectively highlighted statistics, falsely claimed New York and New Jersey were solely responsible for high national death rates and again wrongly asserted that a rise in cases was because of testing.
content: President Trump, in a news conference on Tuesday, cited a slew of statistics to argue that “our strong mitigation efforts are working very well.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $300,000 Homes in Connecticut, Indiana and Oregon
description: A rebuilt cottage with a pollinator garden in Litchfield County, a renovated 1914 house in Indianapolis and a floating house on an island in Portland.
content: This house is in a town of about 3,500 in Litchfield County, 80 miles northeast of New York City and 45 miles southwest of Hartford. Its owner, who is also the listing agent, did a thorough renovation in the last year, replacing the siding, roof, kitchen and bathroom, and updating all systems. He also installed a bluestone patio and created a professionally landscaped pollinator garden with plants native to the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga
title: What Coronavirus Measures Is Your School Taking?
description: We would like to hear from teachers and students about how their schools are preparing for a very different academic year.
content: With the fall semester fast approaching, schools across the United States are scrambling to plan for an uncertain future during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Rush to Treat With Plasma Undermines Studies
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 5, 2020.
content: “I’m not as concerned about the political leaders having a misguided approach to science. What I’m really concerned about is scientists having a misguided approach to science.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Taylor Lorenz
title: F.B.I. Searches Jake Paul’s California Home
description: A SWAT team was used to enter the YouTube star’s mansion in Calabasas, northwest of Los Angeles, on Wednesday, an F.B.I. spokeswoman said.
content: The F.B.I. executed a search warrant early Wednesday morning at the California home of Jake Paul, a brash YouTube provocateur who was recently criticized for hosting a large house party during the pandemic, according to the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Doris Buffett, the Family’s ‘Retail Philanthropist,’ Dies at 92
description: Her younger brother, Warren, entrusted her with vetting requests after he announced his intention to donate nearly his entire fortune. “Warren loves to make money and I love to give it away,” she said.
content: Doris Buffett, a self-styled retail philanthropist who once declared that her billionaire younger brother, Warren Buffett, “loves to make money and I love to give it away,” died on Tuesday at her home in Rockport, Me. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Raises $165 Million With Party in July, Outpacing Biden
description: Democrats announced that their Milwaukee convention would be almost entirely virtual, citing coronavirus concerns. Biden will skip the convention and accept the nomination in Delaware. In primary races, progressives triumphed and a polarizing Republican fell.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: The Universal Loneliness of Powfu
description: On his major label debut EP, the 21-year-old musician from Vancouver follows in the footsteps of lovelorn emo singers and rappers.
content: Want to learn about pop music? Pay more attention to the songs that bubble up to the masses, like gases desperately seeking escape, than to marquee artists’ event releases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: As Smoke Clears in Beirut, Shock Turns to Anger
description: As residents picked up the pieces, many saw the explosion as the culmination of years of mismanagement and neglect by Lebanon’s political leaders.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Since an orphaned shipment of highly explosive chemicals arrived at the port of Beirut in 2013, Lebanese officials treated it the way they have dealt with the country’s lack of electricity, poisonous tap water and overflowing garbage: by bickering and hoping the problem might solve itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sylvia Brownrigg
title: What Parents Leave Behind When They Die
description: Jill McCorkle’s “Hieroglyphics” examines the end of life through the stories of an aging couple and a tragic murder trial.
content: HIEROGLYPHICS By Jill McCorkle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Kathleen Duey, a Mentoring Children’s Book Author, Dies at 69
description: A prolific writer, she published more than 75 books, including a Best Seller and a National Book Award finalist, all while encouraging aspiring authors.
content: In 2013, Kim Zarins was looking for authors to teach a workshop on writing fantasy for children and teens, part of a California State University summer arts program she was organizing. “I had two qualifications,” Ms. Zarins, a professor of English at Cal State, Sacramento, recalled in a phone interview. “You had to be an excellent writer and a generous teacher.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook Removes Trump Campaign’s Misleading Coronavirus Video
description: It was the first time Facebook took down a post by Mr. Trump’s campaign for spreading virus misinformation, but it did not signal a change to the company’s defense of free expression.
content: WASHINGTON — Facebook took down a video posted by the campaign of President Trump on Wednesday in which he claimed children were immune to the coronavirus, a violation of the social network’s rules against misinformation around the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Greta Moran
title: When Disasters Overlap
description: Also this week, how to help a neighbor when it’s hot
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Gluck
title: Fly Casting on City Streets Is Weird. That’s Why I Love It.
description: I’m desperate to find pockets of joy wherever I can. Some people bake bread. I started street-casting on West 12th.
content: I live in New York City, in downtown Manhattan, on the seventh floor of a 13-story apartment building. Two or three times a week, I wake up early, ride the elevator down to my lobby and say good morning to my doorman, in the custom of millions of city dwellers everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anger Rises After Beirut Blast and Evidence Officials Knew of Risks
description: The chemical cache that apparently exploded was not supposed to be in Lebanon, but arrived there on a troubled freighter. Now, Beirut residents are digging out of the devastation, looking for survivors, victims and answers.
content: Rescue workers still struggling to treat thousands of people wounded in an enormous explosion that rocked Beirut turned their attention on Wednesday morning to the desperate search for survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Lost Teenager Found After Spending 9 Days in Washington State Forest
description: After Gia Fuda, 18, ran out of gas in rural Washington, a search for her lasted more than a week in rugged mountains.
content: Early on July 24, Giovanna Fuda left her home in Maple Valley, Wash., and went for a drive. She ended up about 90 miles northeast of her hometown, in a cellphone dead zone, where her car ran out of gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: What Is Ammonium Nitrate, Blamed in the Beirut Explosion?
description: In ordinary circumstances, ammonium nitrate is fertilizer. But when placed under stress of heat and pressure, it acts like a bomb.
content: John Ismay was a bomb disposal officer in the U.S. Navy before he became a reporter for The Times Magazine’s At War section. Here is the information he has gathered about the explosion in Beirut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Welcome Back to Germany. Now Take Your Free Virus Test.
description: The country’s capacity to make testing efficient, affordable and available has distinguished it. Now, to head off a potential second wave, it’s testing anyone returning from a “hot zone” on entry.
content: BERLIN — When she returned to Germany last week from a vacation in Serbia, one of the first things Snjezana Kirstein did was to stop at a pop-up coronavirus testing center at Berlin’s Tegel Aiport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 12 Movies Before They Leave Netflix This Month
description: “Groundhog Day” for when every day feels the same, “Candyman” for when they feel like a nightmare: Watch them while you can in August.
content: This month’s exiting Netflix titles are rather comfort-food heavy: early entries in venerable franchises, classic romances and comedies, and endlessly re-watchable ’80s faves. Or is it just that everything feels like comfort food these days? (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: When the Bronx Was a Forest: Stroll Through the Centuries
description: Yankee Stadium was the site of a salt marsh. Concourse Plaza was a valley. Our critic walks with Eric W. Sanderson, a conservation ecologist.
content: With more residents than Dallas, more than Atlanta and San Francisco combined, the Bronx is a vast, vibrant megalopolis, which also happens to be New York City’s greenest borough. It’s home to the largest urban zoological garden in America, a park system nearly 10 times the size of Manhattan’s Central Park — and the city’s last remaining patch of old growth forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith, Will Heinrich, Martha Schwendener and Jason Farago
title: Four Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the pandemic. Some are open for in-person visits. Here are shows worth viewing either way.
content: Over the past two or three years, Warren Isensee’s abstract paintings, while always good, have taken a sharp turn for the better. For nearly a decade Mr. Isensee, who has been exhibiting since 1998, cultivated a distinctive geometry of parallel lines whose softened edges and pulsing color contrasts conjured the tubular glow of neon, compartmentalizing them into squares and rectangles with black outlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberly Bradley
title: What Worried Artists in Lockdown? The Same Things as Everyone Else
description: A major European show of work made during coronavirus confinement deals with boredom, doubt and isolation.
content: BREGENZ, Austria — A tuba sitting on a rolling upholstered chair moves through a small room, to the sounds of a Shostakovich waltz. From the space’s perimeter, a man in a white shirt pulls and spins the improvised contraption across the floor with ropes, like a puppeteer or a dance partner. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma and Edward Wong
title: Another Inspector General Resigns Amid Questions About Pompeo
description: Stephen J. Akard became the State Department’s internal watchdog after his predecessor was fired by President Trump at the urging of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who has been under investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — The State Department’s acting watchdog has resigned from his post less than three months after replacing the previous inspector general, whom President Trump fired in May, the department said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Anderson
title: How to Proactively Prepare for Distance Learning
description: This fall doesn’t have to be like the spring.
content: Normally we rely on teachers and counselors or coaches and people in our communities to help us spot problems, then identify solutions. We try to build a village to not have to do everything alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik and Joe Coscarelli
title: Takeoff, Member of Migos, Is Accused of Rape in Lawsuit
description: The civil complaint, filed in Los Angeles, accuses Takeoff, one of three members of the hip-hop group, of assaulting a woman during a house party in June.
content: Takeoff, a rapper who is part of the Atlanta trio Migos, has been accused of rape in a lawsuit filed Wednesday in Los Angeles by a woman who said she was assaulted at a house party in Encino, Calif., in late June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Godspell’ in 2020: Masks, Partitions and a Contactless Crucifixion
description: The first professional musical staged in the United States since theater shut down is also a de facto public health experiment.
content: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — And on the eighth day, Jesus wept.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Secret to Great Empanadas
description: It’s popcorn, as J. Kenji López-Alt learned from the Colombian chef Carlos Gaviria.
content: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt has a fascinating article in The Times this week about a trip he took with his wife, Adri, to her native Colombia, and the empanadas (above) he learned to make there with the chef Carlos Gaviria. Kenji was left speechless, he wrote, by the secret ingredient used to make the dough: popcorn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Boyne

author: By Allan Lichtman
title: He Predicted Trump’s Win in 2016. Now He’s Ready to Call 2020.
description: Most historians just study the past. But Allan Lichtman has successfully predicted the future.
content: Right now, polls say Joe Biden has a healthy lead over President Trump. But we’ve been here before (cue 2016), and the polls were, frankly, wrong. One man, however, was not. The historian Allan Lichtman was the lonely forecaster who predicted Mr. Trump’s victory in 2016 — and also prophesied the president would be impeached. That’s two for two. But Professor Lichtman’s record goes much deeper. In 1980, he developed a presidential prediction model that retrospectively accounted for 120 years of U.S. election history. Over the past four decades, his system has accurately called presidential victors, from Ronald Reagan in ’84 to, well, Mr. Trump in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich, Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump’s Bank Was Subpoenaed by N.Y. Prosecutors in Criminal Inquiry
description: The subpoena, sent to Deutsche Bank, suggests that the inquiry into President Trump’s business practices is more wide-ranging than previously known.
content: The New York prosecutors who are seeking President Trump’s tax records have also subpoenaed his longtime lender, a sign that their criminal investigation into Mr. Trump’s business practices is more wide-ranging than previously known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Garcia
title: Scrapbooking Isn’t Just for White People
description: People of color who craft are done being overlooked as customers and designers.
content: Tazhiana Gordon, describes herself as a messy, mixed-media kind of scrapbooker. She uses brightly colored inks and stamps and stickers to layer compositions on paper for personal albums, photos of which she shares with a close-knit online community of fellow crafters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: These Rolls Will Change the Way You See Sourdough
description: The baker Bryan Ford’s pan de coco, made with coconut milk, does not look like European sourdough — and that’s part of the pleasure.
content: It’s not that Bryan Ford didn’t love those tall, quintessentially crusty, flour-dusted, rustic French and Italian sourdough loaves — the kind you’ve seen cross-sectioned and shot from every angle on bread blogs and in cookbooks and on Instagram. The kind an algorithm may have even directed you toward with a far higher frequency since the pandemic pushed more home cooks to care for sourdough starters. He loved those breads! But Ford, a Honduran-American baker from New Orleans, also wondered why other breads weren’t valued in the same way, and why other doughs, especially doughs that predated the sourdough fad, and that went through their own processes of wild fermentations in home kitchens all over the world, were left out of the conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: It’s (Almost) Business as Usual at the Salzburg Festival
description: A bustling event for a wealthy and elegant audience is underway in Austria, despite the coronavirus pandemic.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — A visit to the Salzburg Festival has been a summer tradition for Jos Baeck for nearly half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priyanka Runwal
title: Where to Cool Off on the Savanna? Mother Chimps Know Best
description: When forests and woodlands don’t provide a respite from the heat, these primates find cooling centers in their arid landscape.
content: Everyone needs to cool off on a scorching summer day, even chimpanzees. Where do the primates go on sizzling days when woodlands and forests don’t provide respite from the heat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Shane Goldmacher and Matt Stevens
title: After 6 Weeks, Victors Are Declared in 2 N.Y. Congressional Primaries
description: Representative Carolyn Maloney and Councilman Ritchie Torres won in New York City after a Democratic primary that raised concerns about mail-in voting.
content: After six weeks of delays, the New York City Board of Elections confirmed results in a pair of congressional races on Tuesday evening, delivering victories to a longtime Democratic incumbent and a young city lawmaker who could be a trailblazer for gay and African-American rights.
source.name: The New York Times
